title: How DNS Really Works — A Practical Overview
content:
Domain Name System (DNS) is the phonebook of the internet. When you type a domain, DNS resolves a human-readable name to an IP address.

Key components:

  • Resolvers — clients that query DNS.
  • Authoritative nameservers — hold the records for a zone.
  • Records — A/AAAA for IPs, CNAME for aliases, MX for mail, etc.

Practical tips: keep TTLs reasonable for services that change IPs, use health-checked failover where appropriate, and secure zones with DNSSEC for authenticity.

title: Backend For Frontend (BFF): Patterns and When to Use It
content:
The Backend For Frontend (BFF) pattern adds a small backend service tailored to the needs of a specific frontend (web, mobile). It helps by aggregating multiple APIs, shaping responses, and handling auth complexity.

Benefits:

  • Reduced client complexity — the BFF translates and composes data.
  • Performance optimisations — returns only needed fields or combines calls.
  • Separation of concerns — keeps frontend-specific logic server-side.

When to use: when multiple frontends have divergent needs, or when you want to centralise frontend-specific security/aggregation logic.
